data.title: Update GLSL Shadergen.

milestone.title: OpenGL3
milestone.description:
This milestone tracks the progress of adding an OpenGL rendering backend to the engine alongside the current DirectX backend, which is unfortunately the only backend of the abstracted GFX interface. This will allow OpenGL rendering on multiple platforms, but specifically OXS and Linux.

[Working branch.](https://github.com/BeamNG/Torque3D/tree/dev_linux_opengl)

data.body: Not used on DX9.

data.body:
These changes do anything in DX9, the "sampler register" are asigned on hlsl files.

In OpenGL is necessary to pass the position of the samplers before compiling the glsl program for assign ShaderData samplers to correct index used with CustomMaterial, PostEffect and GFXStateBlockData.

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body: Fixed the assert crash by making sure the glow material instance keeps the original material instance's user object for issue [437](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues/437)

data.title: T2D style 'Stock colors'

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
This commit implements stock colors as they are implemented in T2D.
It allows for using predefined stock colors e.g.:
`%object.color = "OrangeRed";`
Instead of
`%object.color = "255 69 0";`

milestone.title: OpenGL3
milestone.description:
This milestone tracks the progress of adding an OpenGL rendering backend to the engine alongside the current DirectX backend, which is unfortunately the only backend of the abstracted GFX interface. This will allow OpenGL rendering on multiple platforms, but specifically OXS and Linux.

[Working branch.](https://github.com/BeamNG/Torque3D/tree/dev_linux_opengl)

data.body:
OpenGL and DirectX11 not support FFP, and GFDevice::disableShaders has not the necessary information to decide the shader to be used.

GFDevice::SetupGenericShaders is used instead of GFDevice::disableShaders.

GFDevice::disableShaders will be deprecated on T3D 4.0

data.title: Rift and Vehicles do not play nice (crash)
data.body: As described [here](http://www.garagegames.com/community/forums/viewthread/135827), when mounting a Vehicle with the Rift enabled, the engine crashes.

data.title: Revision of #605: requested alterations.
data.body:
origin: http://www.garagegames.com/community/resource/view/6538/1

Verification methodology/usage:
Functions for stock player physics.
1) Add a convex shape named Hitbox0, Hitbox1 ect (up to 20) to a player model. Can be children of bones so that they animate. (If not, falls back to stock bounding box + percentile lookups.)
2) Go to game scripts\server\projectile.cs
in the method ProjectileData::onCollision(%data, %proj, %col, %fade, %pos, %normal, %hitbox), flip on the remmed out comment. %hitbox should reflect a given hitbox mesh struck.

data.title: Player hitboxes
data.body:
origin: http://www.garagegames.com/community/resource/view/6538/1

Verification methodology/usage:
Functions for stock player physics.
1) Add a convex shape named HB0, HB1 ect (up to 20) to a player model. Can be children of bones so that they animate.
2) Flip on bool mUseHitboxes; in the respective datablock entry.
3) Go to game scripts\server\projectile.cs
in the method ProjectileData::onCollision(%this,%obj,%col,%fade,%pos,%normal,%hitbox), flip on the remmed out comment.
4)???
5) Profit from the new functionality in your game. (Personally, we're using it for things like critical points.)

**_Do note this is intended to be a transitional commit, letting folks work with a form compatible with the proposed alterations involved in the proposed upcoming component system.**_

data.title: Particle Accumulation on Damage (Yet another one-liner)
data.body: Given that T3D does not allow for mixed particle blend types (smoke and fire particularly), this allows the accumulation, rather than the replacement of particle emissions based on damage levels. If this is desirable, player and rigidshape methods are (relatively) simple to port on over as well. (Though player, vehicle, and rigidshape naming conventions for the VC_BUBBLE_EMITTER vs VC_NUM_BUBBLE_EMITTERS differ, so likely best to pick an Enum nomenclature first.)

data.title: simple alteration to allow for negative damage (repair).
data.body: This does expose a small miscalculation with damageradius, where the numbers could go negative with large destructible objects. As it's a percentile, clamped it from 0 to 1.

data.title: removes non-functional shield and invincibility functionality.

data.title: Rename enum GFXTextureProfile::None for avoid conficts on Linux.
data.body: Some Linux headers define None, causing conflic with T3D enum GFXTextureProfile::Compression::None.

data.title: Rename Status enum for avoid conficts on Linux.
data.body: Some Linux headers define Status, causing conflic with T3D enums.

data.title: Issue 437
data.body:
Fix for [#437](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues/437)

Imperfect in that the materials still can render weirdly when combined with alpha, but it fixes the assert by making sure the glow material instance retains the user object(which the foliage shader consts check for)

data.title: TorqueScript unit test

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
Adds a unit test to the engine that tests some basic functionality of TorqueScript.

Can easily be extended later to test more things, but this acts as a solid starting point.
